page.title: 12FARMING AROUND SHERIFF HUT'N
page.content: Much permanent pasture still shows and 'Rigg and Furrow'pattern of mediaeval farming in small fields,but with many made into larger ones,still hedged though cut low by machines.Some farms are worked by the owners alone,with expensive machinery and casual labour when needed.Some employ one or two men otherwise relying on contractors for tilling,manuring and spraying.A racing stable with 50 horses in training, employs 24 men on 50 acres of gallops. Two men still own or rent small fields scattered in the area.Chief crops are wheat,barley,oats,oil seed rape, potatoes and sugar beet.Pigs are reared intensively.There are also sheep,beef cattle(free range and housed)and two dairy herds. Old barns are being replaced by large corrugated iron sheds,to house the larger modern machines.
